content.webTitle: Neil Warnock says he has a debt to repay upon Crystal Palace return

fields.headline: Neil Warnock says he has a debt to repay upon Crystal Palace return
fields.bodyText: Neil Warnock says that his return to Crystal Palace gives him the opportunity to “pay back” the club for rescuing him from a dark period before his first tenure at Selhurst Park. The 65-year-old oversaw training on Thursday for the first time since signing a two-year contract to replace Tony Pulis – a session that included Wilfred Zaha, whose return from Manchester United on a season-long loan is complete pending insurance formalities – before explaining that the prospect of keeping his former employers in the Premier League made the job straightforward to accept. Warnock also said that he had been in the running to return last season before Pulis was appointed. “Things happen for a reason at times and I’ve felt this time that it’s an opportunity to pay [Palace] back a bit. To give back to the fans, who have been brilliant. It’ll take a lot of hard work, I know there’s going to be ups and downs and criticisms along the way, but for the next eight months I’m going to work as hard as I’ve ever worked. “ You don’t often get a chance to repay and I think I owe them a little bit, so it’s great to be given that chance.” Warnock was referring to circumstances surrounding his arrival at the club in October 2007, when he was “at a low” after being relegated on goal difference with Sheffield United amid controversy about Carlos Tevez’s eligibility to play for West Ham. “Originally I would have liked to keep Sheffield up and then packed it in,” he said. “But it didn’t work out like that and I had two or three months of moping around feeling sorry for myself. Then Simon [Jordan] came along, who I’ve known for donkey’s years, and we became very good friends. He got me down on false pretences of having a look at what they’ve got and asking me about a few players, and then it was ‘why don’t you just do it for a few months?’.” Warnock’s first spell at Palace ended when the club went into administration in 2010, news of which was first imparted when the team arrived for a fixture against Saturday’s opponents, Newcastle. He has since managed Queens Park Rangers and Leeds United; the former was his last crack at the Premier League, one that ended unceremoniously when he was sacked by Tony Fernandes in January 2012. Since leaving Elland Road 15 months later, he had been happy to bat away any offers that did not appeal to him and his wife, Sharon. “I wouldn’t have come [if she had not wanted to]. There were a couple of clubs – you know me, I get tempted with anyone, even in the bottom division – where I thought I ‘I’ll do that’, until she said she’d leave me,” he joked. Warnock also said that the Palace co-chairman Steve Parish, whose falling out with Pulis led to the latter’s departure, had not offered the position to anybody else. “I think before Tony came there was a possibility that he wasn’t going to and we talked then, but then he changed his mind and did fantastically. So I think Steve’s always known I’m available – I didn’t really have to tell him. He says he never offered it to anybody beforehand, and if I’m honest I’m not really bothered. I’m not bothered who was here, who was in the running, what the betting was.” He emphasised that he had not sought assurances from Parish about transfer policy or funds, despite the well-documented problems the subject had caused with Pulis. “You don’t talk about anything like that. I didn’t talk about money or anything, it’s the opportunity. You don’t get opportunities like this very often – in different circumstances there might have been four or five other managers who would all have enjoyed it as well. I’m very fortunate that I’ve got the job now and I’m going to really enjoy it if I can.” Zaha’s return is likely to be the first of several additions to the squad before Monday night’s transfer deadline, although Warnock – who said he had received 320 messages from agents offering him players – does not envisage further movement before the weekend. “I think it’s right for Wilfried,” he said of Zaha. “I think there’s still a lot more to come from him. He’s one of those lads that people accuse at times of not having the right attitude, but I’ve never seen that. If you’re willing to spend the time with Wilfried, he wants to learn all the time and I think that’s a great attribute. So I think you’ll see a different Wilfried and hopefully he’ll have a great season.”
